title: Severe Storms in the Southeast US Leave 1 Dead and Cause Widespread Power Outages
message:
CANTON, Ga.—A weather system that produced severe thunderstorms late into the night in the Southeast left one man dead in Georgia, caused damage in a South Carolina town and left hundreds of thousands of electricity customers without power for a time.
Power outages in southeastern Tennessee and northern Georgia had declined to about 30,000 by Wednesday morning, down from more than 200,000 in Georgia alone.
Wednesday’s remaining outages were most concentrated around the town of Ellijay in the north Georgia mountains.
In Orangeburg, South Carolina, straight-line winds caused damage in the city’s downtown district, blowing down metal from roofs and wood from awnings of downtown businesses.
Officials across southeastern Tennessee and northern Georgia said roads were blocked Wednesday because of downed trees and power lines.
event_breakdown:
1. A person died as a result of severe thunderstorms in Georgia.
2. Straight-line winds caused damage in a South Carolina town, leaving many without power.
3. Power outages continued in Georgia, Tennessee, and North Carolina.
4. A tornado touched down in Texas, damaging cars and buildings.
5. Flash flooding killed a woman in Tennessee.

title: Officials declare California wildfires have burned 5 times more area this year alone :  We are not just in a fire season , we are in a fire year
message:
Officials declare California wildfires have burned 5 times more area this year alone: 'We are not just in a fire season, we are in a fire year'Wildfires in California burned more than 300,000 acres through the third week of July.
It is still relatively early in California's wildfire season, but it is unfortunately already off to a roaring start.
Through the third week of July, the number of acres burned had nearly tripled the average of the past five years, according to Cal Fire.
There have been more than 4,000 wildland fires and over 2,500 structural fires in California so far.
Why is an active wildfire season in California important?
event_breakdown:
California Wildfires

Several wildfires continue to burn across California, where officials have declared an emergency.

Major fires have been reported near Route 299, the Easy Fire in Simi Valley, the Ranch 2 Fire west of Azusa, the Freeway Fire near Castaic, among others.

The remnants of what was once the most active wildfire season in state history continue to burn across California.

title: Valley News - Why does Vermont keep flooding ? It complicated , but experts warn it could become the norm
message:
Vermont is flooding.
Warming atmosphereExtreme flooding conditions like these are often the result of random, short-term natural weather patterns heightened by long-term, human-caused climate change.
With climate change, storms are forming in a warmer atmosphere, making extreme rainfall a more frequent reality.
Heavily manipulated riversVermont’s history of heavily manipulating its rivers and streams also plays a role in increased flooding, Vermont Agency of Natural Resources secretary Julie Moore said.
A crumbling dam systemDams in Vermont are increasingly at risk as climate change brings heavier rains and more powerful storms.
event_breakdown:
Vermont flooding
Rivers rearranged for 20th century water laws meant less flooding from storms — and more flooding from beavers.
As climate change brings heavier rains and more powerful storms, weaker beaver dams are no longer breaking, flooding human property that rivers didn’t reach before
Vermont is full of beaverish dams. Ninety-five percent of its rivers and streams feature dams built by water-loving critters, many of them not that new — some are made from trees that predate the formation of the United States.

message: Vermont’s governor says the latest storms to hit the state have undone much of the cleanup and recovery work done since its last major bout of flooding only weeks ago, and he is calling on residents to “stick together” amid fears that more bad weather was on its way
event_breakdown:
Burlington, Vermont, USA
Montpelier, Vermont, USA
Essex, Vermont, USA
Montpelier, Vermont, USA
Several towns in Vermont were affected by heavy rain and flooding on Monday, with dozens of roads shut down and many residents forced to evacuate. In Montpelier, the state's capital, the governor declared a state of emergency and activated the National Guard to help with relief efforts. In Burlington, city officials opened an emergency operations center and directed residents to several shelters that were set up throughout the city. In Essex, residents were ordered to evacuate after a nearby dam was breached, and other towns reported significant damage to homes and businesses. The governor is urging Vermonters to stay safe and stick together as the state braces for more rain and potentially severe flooding.

A government statement says the landslide Wednesday blocked the river that feeds into the Fraser River, and a sudden release of water "may cause rapid rises in river levels downstream along the Fraser River" south to Hope, B.C.
The River Forecast Centre has issued a flood warning for the Chilcotin River upstream of the landslide and a flood watch downstream.

title: Caribbean conservationists urge greater focus on disaster risk management
message:
Caribbean conservationists are encouraging small island developing states (SIDS) to place greater attention on disaster risk management and prevention measures, so that the appropriate strategies are in place and actionable before the countries are devastated by natural disasters.
Speaking at a Global Conservation Connection webinar on Tuesday under the topic ‘Disaster Risk Management and Hurricanes in the Caribbean’, keynote speaker Dr Trevor Johnson Jr, from The Bahamas, a consultant with the Inter-American Development Bank and a regional disaster management specialist with the Pacific Disaster Center, stated that issues surrounding disaster management should be at the forefront of the agenda of all governments within the Caribbean region.
He argued that as disasters impacted every socio-economic sector, deliberate, laser-focused and pragmatic regional discourse is necessary, and that the issues of disaster risk management demand a full community approach.
“Disaster risk management is everyone’s business,” he said.
She continued that St Lucia has had challenges with disaster risk management, particularly in the town of Soufrière, which is extremely vulnerable to hurricanes and storm surge damages.

title: Loudoun County farmers can apply for emergency drought aid
message:
LOUDOUN COUNTY, Va. (DC News Now) — Farmers in Loudoun County are eligible for emergency loan assistance from the federal government due to the drought during this year’s growing season.
U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) Secretary Thomas Vilsack declared Loudoun and 14 other Virginia counties as “primary natural disaster areas,” allowing the Farm Service Agency (FSA) to offer emergency loans and other assistance to farmers impacted by the drought.
Farmers have eight months to apply for the loans.
Farmers in Loudoun County specifically can also receive support through the Loudoun County Department of Economic Development and Virginia Cooperative Extension.
For the latest news, weather, sports, and streaming video, head to DC News Now | Washington, DC.

title: National Hurricane Center tracking possible tropical storm formation near Bahamas , Florida – ICSF
message:
A​ disturbance in the Atlantic continues to be watched for possible formation into a tropical storm, but there are multiple scenarios in play when it comes to the track of this system as it nears the Bahamas and the southeastern United States by this weekend.
The tropical wave that might eventually grow into a tropical depression or storm is located over the Leeward Islands, or near the “X” in the graphic below, according to the National Hurricane Center.
C​omputer models suggest wind shear may be relatively light, and there’s plenty of warm ocean water ahead of this system to fuel its development near the Bahamas or the Gulf of Mexico.
However, this rather large tropical disturbance will likely have to interact with land along the way, particularly Hispaniola and Cuba, but also possibly Florida.
So, it may take some time for one area of thunderstorms to persist over water, lower surface pressure and begin the process of developing a tropical depression, if that happens at all.

title: B . C . issues flood warning , watches after landslide blocks river , forces evacuations
message:
A sudden release of water from the blocked Chilcotin River "may cause rapid rises in river levels downstream along the Fraser River" south to Hope, the government says.
A government statement says the landslide Wednesday blocked the river that feeds into the Fraser River, and a sudden release of water "may cause rapid rises in river levels downstream along the Fraser River" south to Hope, B.C.
The River Forecast Centre has issued a flood warning for the Chilcotin River upstream of the landslide and a flood watch downstream.
A flood watch is also in place for the Fraser River from the Chilcotin River confluence to Hope as well as a high streamflow advisory for the Fraser River west of Hope.
Evacuation orders issued Wednesday remain in place, covering 107 kilometres along both sides of the Chilcotin River, after the Cariboo Regional District said there was an immediate danger to life and safety due to flooding.

title: August Weather Headlines
message:
HARRISONBURG, Va. (WHSV) - As July turns into August, the final month of summer has officially begun, but will the weather look any different from the last few dry months?
With late summer knocking on the doorsteps, tropical systems will start to become more common by the end of the month.
Activity historically starts to climb late month into September.
However, tropical systems become much more common from late August through October.
These types of systems often produce widespread, soaking rainfall, and is likely the sole way the region will break the drought.

title: Hurricane preparedness : Tropical terms to get familiar with
message:
Tropical Cyclone: Any tropical area of low pressure found anywhere around the world.
Potential Tropical Cyclone: Designated by the National Hurricane Center when a disturbance that has not yet met all of the meteorological characteristics to become tropical but has the strong potential to become one.
The disturbance will receive this designation when it has a strong chance to bring tropical storm or hurricane conditions to land within 48 hours.
Tropical Outlook: Issued by the National Hurricane Center to highlight an area of disturbed weather that has a chance to develop into a tropical depression, storm or hurricane.
Tropical Advisory: Issued when a tropical depression develops.
location: Tropical Advisory: Issued when a tropical depression develops.

Alaska

During the past couple of weeks, Alaska has seen a heatwave with temperatures well above average. As the result of a dome of high pressure over the region, the heatwave is being accompanied by a brand-new high-temperature mark: 90 degrees. Finally, on Friday, the high pressure mass should crack, and it will be followed by a cooldown by the end of Friday and possibly into next weekend.

90 degrees was previously recorded in Kotzebue on July 27, 2009. The last summer to have a top temperature in the 90s was 2004, not 2012. Some spots in the eastern Alaska Panhandle saw top temperatures in the mid-80s throughout the day on Thursday.

Other sources have reported all-time heat records in Alaska occurring in several other cities and towns even before the Kotzebue area broke the new wooden record.

Heat in western Alaska has caused drought; burn restrictions are in place across the state.

Fire

Wildfires are raging worldwide. Over the last few days, firefighters in Siberia battled massive and old wildfires; Northern Ontario continues to fight a dependably slow wildfire known as Red Lake Fire 29.

title: Tropical Storm Carlotta strengthens over Pacific Ocean as it moves away from Mexico – Winnipeg Free Press
message:
MIAMI (AP) — Tropical Storm Carlotta is growing stronger over the Pacific Ocean as it moves away from Mexico and could become a hurricane by Thursday evening, forecasters said.
The National Hurricane Center in Miami said Thursday morning that Carlotta’s maximum sustained winds had grown to 60 mph (95 kph).
The system was centered about 345 miles (630 kilometers) southwest of Manzanilla, Mexico, moving northwest at 12 mph (19 kph).
Swells generated by the storm will likely cause life-threatening surf and rip current conditions through the weekend along Mexico’s west-central mainland coast and the southern Baja California peninsula, the hurricane center warned.
event_breakdown: Tropical Storm Carlotta.

title: Forecasters predict Tropical Storm Carlotta to grow into hurricane
message:
Tropical Storm Carlotta off the western coast of Mexico is expected to grow into a hurricane, forecasters said.
Photo courtesy of NOAAAug. 1 (UPI) -- The National Hurricane Center said Thursday that Pacific Ocean Tropical Storm Carlotta is expected to become a hurricane late Thursday or Friday.
"This motion is expected to continue [Thursday], followed by a turn toward the west on Friday and a continued westward motion through the weekend," the National Hurricane Center said.
"Strengthening is forecast during the next couple of days and Carlotta is expected to become a hurricane today or [Friday]."
The center said its tropical storm winds extend 60 miles from the eye.

title: BC Issues Flood Warning , Watches After Landslide Blocks River , Forces Evacuations
message:
A massive amount of debris from a landslide damming the Chilcotin River in British Columbia’s central Interior could give way within the next 24 to 48 hours.
Wagner told a news briefing that the riverbed below the slide is dry, and officials aren’t certain about the potential downstream impacts when the dam is breached.
But she says it’s clear there would be “a mass of water” coming down the Chilcotin, which flows south into the Fraser River.
Evacuation orders span 107 square kilometres along the Chilcotin, with the regional officials saying the slide poses an “immediate danger to life and safety.”The district says 60 properties are covered by the orders, including 12 homes with an estimated 13 residents.
Wagner says the slide is “massive,” with material piled 30 metres high and stretching 600 metres in length, completely blocking the flow of the Chilcotin.

title: Wildfires rage in Balkans and Greece
message:
ANTONIO BRONIC/REUTERSFierce wildfires, propelled by strong winds, ravaged areas of Greece and the Balkans on Tuesday, destroying forests and homes and forcing the evacuation of an Albanian resort town, local officials reported.
The area has experienced higher-than-normal temperatures and arid conditions throughout the previous month, establishing perfect circumstances for the outbreak of wildfires, according to scientists.
In recent years, Greece has experienced an increase in wildfire occurrences during progressively hotter and drier summers, a trend that scientists attribute to climate change.
The country has been grappling with hundreds of wildfires since May, coinciding with its record-breaking hottest June and longest-ever heatwave.
Europe is experiencing the most rapid warming of any continent globally, with Greece among nations most severely impacted by the consequences of anthropogenic climate change, reported Euronews.

Greece, Balkans wildfires

title: Why focusing on a hurricane category is downright dangerous
message:
Dennis Mersereau Digital Journalist The wind scale doesn’t take into account all of a storm’s life-threatening hazardsThe streets in eastern Texas resembled rivers the week the downpours started.
Monstrous hurricanes are often reduced to a single category as they swirl toward land.
“The Category 4 storm will approach landfall…” is a simple and easy way to convey the maximum winds within a storm in the easiest way possible.
But reducing a storm to its category and focusing solely on the storm’s winds can have terrible consequences in the face of a multitude of other hazards.
DON'T MISS: Tropical systems don’t need a name to trigger devastating floodsThe Saffir-Simpson scale focuses on windsMeteorologists use the Saffir-Simpson Hurricane Wind Scale (SSHWS) to categorize and communicate a hurricane’s maximum sustained winds in an easy-to-relate way.
event_breakdown:
1. Dennis Mersereau Digital Journalist writes, "The streets in eastern Texas resembled rivers the week the downpours started. The Saffir-Simpson scale says a storm was not a hurricane at this point. But it seems the storm remains a Gulf tropical cyclone."
2. The streets turned into rivers after the week downpours started, but the Saffir-Simpson scale did not categorize the storm as hurricane even though it was an important storm on the Gulf of Mexico."
3. Monstrous hurricanes can be reduced to a single category, but focusing only on the storm’s winds can have terrible consequences in the face of other hazards.
4. Dennis Mersereau Digital Journalist reports, "The Category 4 storm will approach landfall somewhere between Cameron and Galveston overnight on Tuesday, with sustained maximum winds of 145 miles per hour.
5. The Saffir-Simpson scale measures the hurricane’s winds but fails to report other important issues in the storm."

title: Flash floods  imminent  after Chilcotin landslide : officials
message:
Interior trapped one man who had to be rescued, according to video shared from the sceneEmergency officials say flash floods are "imminent" and could happen within 24 or 48 hours after a landslide blocked the Chilcotin River in British Columbia's Cariboo region.
River Forecast Centre issued a flood warning for the Chilcotin River upstream of the landslide.
It's also issued a flood watch for the Fraser River, from where it meets the Chilcotin River downstream to Hope, B.C.
Ma asked residents to stay away from the banks of the Chilcotin River from Hanceville to the Fraser River and anywhere on or along the Fraser River from the Chilcotin River to Hope.
Ma told reporters while evacuation orders do not affect many people at this time, an evacuation centre has been set up in Williams Lake.
event_breakdown:
Flood warning issued for Chilcotin River due to landslide in British Columbia's Cariboo region
Flood watch in place for Fraser River from Chilcotin River to Hope, B.C.
Residents urged to stay away from banks of Chilcotin River and Fraser River from Chilcotin River to Hope.

title: Invest 97L Could Pose Threat To Florida
message:
(Miami, FL) -- Forecasters are tracking a large tropical wave as it gets closer to Florida.
The latest update from the National Hurricane Center shows that the system is located near the Lesser Antilles, creating disorganized showers and thunderstorms.
There is a 60-percent chance the storm will develop into a tropical depression in the next week as it travels toward the Bahamas and most of Florida.

State emergency management officials are urging residents to make sure they have a plan in place before a disaster hits.

title: At least 30 dead after Typhoon Gaemi cut off towns in China Hunan province
message:
Hong Kong CNN —Heavy rains and floods from Typhoon Gaemi caused at least 30 deaths and left 35 people missing across eight towns in the southern Chinese province of Hunan, state-run news agency Xinhua reported on Thursday, citing local authorities.
On Thursday, rescue teams reached eight towns that had been cut off from the outside world since last Sunday, due to destroyed infrastructure and power grids.
Typhoon Gaemi initially made landfall in China on the evening of Thursday July 25, with winds approaching 110 kph (70 mph).
The storm previously caused torrential flooding in Taiwan, with rainfall in five townships totaling over 1,285mm (50 inches).
Footage shows flooding and torrential winds in Nantou, Taiwan on July 25, 2024.
event_breakdown:
China - Heavy rains and floods from Typhoon Gaemi caused at least 30 deaths and left 35 people missing across eight towns in the southern Chinese province of Hunan, state-run news agency Xinhua reported on Thursday, citing local authorities.
Taiwan - Typhoon Gaemi initially made landfall in China on the evening of Thursday July 25, with winds approaching 110 kph (70 mph).

title: 1 killed , nearly 10K acres burned in three wildfires along Colorado Front Range
message:
Aerial and ground firefighting crews responding to the Quarry Fire in Jefferson County.
(Jefferson County Sheriff's Office)Thousands of Coloradans remain evacuated from their homes as three major wildfires burn along the Front Range, and authorities say at least one person has been killed.
Quarry FireA third fire burning in Jefferson County on the southwest edge of the Denver metro area has prompted the evacuations of nearly 600 homes nearby.
More than 750,000 acres have burned in California already this year, nearly 30 times the total acreage burned at this point in 2023.
The U.S. Drought Monitor shows that much of the northern Front Range is experiencing moderate drought conditions, and an area spanning from Jefferson County to northern Larimer County is in severe drought.
event_breakdown: Three major wildfires burning in Front Range of Colorado, prompting evacuations

title: At least 30 dead after Typhoon Gaemi cut off towns in China Hunan province
message:
At least 30 dead after Typhoon Gaemi cut off towns in China’s Hunan provinceHeavy rains and floods from Typhoon Gaemi caused at least 30 deaths and left 35 people missing across eight towns in the southern Chinese province of Hunan, state-run news agency Xinhua reported on Thursday, citing local authorities.
On Thursday, rescue teams reached eight towns that had been cut off from the outside world since last Sunday, due to destroyed infrastructure and power grids.
Typhoon Gaemi initially made landfall in China on the evening of Thursday July 25, with winds approaching 110 kph (70 mph).
The storm previously caused torrential flooding in Taiwan, with rainfall in five townships totaling over 1,285mm (50 inches).
Typhoon Gaemi was deflected off its forecasted track by Taiwan’s mountainous terrain and spent more than six hours offshore, making a loop near the Hualien coastline instead of making landfall on the evening of Wednesday, July 24.
event_breakdown: Heavy rains and floods from Typhoon Gaemi caused at least 30 deaths and left 35 people missing across eight towns in the southern Chinese province of Hunan.

message:
The tropical disturbance in the Atlantic has been designated as Invest 97L by the National Hurricane Center and has a high chance of development in the eastern Gulf of Mexico by the end of the weekend or early next week.
Invest 97-L is a well-defined tropical wave near Hispaniola that the NHC is giving a high 70% chance for development over the next several days.
It is now forecast to move over Cuba and will likely push into the eastern Gulf of Mexico.

title: Flooding hits Indy roads during evening commute . Flood watch continues
message:
Interstate 465 near Lawrence is closed at a standstill as a storm dumped rain on parts of Indianapolis during afternoon commutes Thursday.
WTHR captured footage of the flooding on I-465 near Fall Creek Road and the Shadeland/56th Street exit on the city's northeast side.
The National Weather Service Indianapolis issued a flood watch until 9:45 p.m. for parts of Indy and its northern metro area, including Fishers, Noblesville, Lawrence, and Speedway.
Live video footage of flooding on I-465 near Fall Creek Road.
This article originally appeared on Indianapolis Star: Indianapolis area under flood watch

title: EXPLAINER : Why  tornado  sirens are activated for wind events
message:
(WOWT) - Outdoor sirens aren’t just used for tornado warnings; they may also be activated for wind events.
Sirens are also activated when there is a Destructive Severe Thunderstorm Warning.
Siren Activation Criteria (WOWT)Regardless of the reason for activation, if you hear outdoor sirens you should seek shelter immediately and make sure you have a way to get severe weather updates.
If the sirens are being tested, of course, there is no need for concern.
Wednesday’s storms brought wind gusts up to 92 mph, which would be considered the strength of an EF-1 tornado and a Category 1 hurricane!

title: Tropical Track Shifts Toward Gulf - Louisiana Could Feel Effects
message:
Forecasters with the National Hurricane Center have been monitoring a tropical wave as it moved across the Atlantic Ocean.
Here is the track forecast from the early morning hours of July 31st.
NHC.noaa.gov NHC.noaa.gov loading...Over the past 12 to 24 hours track model forecasts have shifted more to the west.
One tropical model is particularly troublesome as it suggests the system will enter the Gulf of Mexico, strengthen, and then approach the Florida Panhandle.
By the way, should the system earn a name as a tropical storm it would be called Debby.
location: Based on the provided information, the most specific location where the main event may take place is the Florida Panhandle.
event_breakdown: Tropical wave near Atlantic, forecast to enter Gulf of Mexico, possibly threaten Florida panhandle

title: FEMA announces $1 . 2M to restore Creole Park
message:
CAMERON PARISH, La.
(KPLC) - FEMA has announced that it will be providing Cameron Parish with $1,281,178 in federal grant funding to assist with Hurricane Laura aid, according to Sen. John Kennedy.
The funds have been earmarked to restore Creole Park which was damaged during the storm.

title: Tricky tropical forecast ; Intense heat locally over the next few days
message:
Temperatures will drop to the middle and low 90s this weekend as our attention turns to the Gulf of Mexico.
An area of disturbed weather should move into the Gulf or near the southern Florida Peninsula on Saturday.
This area will track north and may impact Florida, and possibly other regions of the Gulf Coast and East Coast.
More heat is expected, and a heat advisory has been issued for portions of our area on Friday.
Most models anticipate a track near, with the system emerging into the Gulf or near south Florida by Saturday.
event_breakdown:
Gulf of Mexico: A system is being monitored that might develop into a cyclone.
Southern Florida Peninsula: An area of disturbed weather is expected to move into the Gulf or onto the Southern Florida Peninsula on Saturday.
